titleStmt.title: Grammar of Tamil (koṭun tamiḻ), by Beschi

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

msContents.summary: A copy of the grammar of the Common Tamil composed in 1728 in Latin by the Italian Jesuit Giuseppe Costantino Beschi (1680-1747).

msItem.author: Beschi

filiation.p: BnF Indien 191 contains its French translation.

msItem.incipit:
Religiosis Tamulicæ linguæ
Candidatis
C. J. Beschius salutem in Dno
Plures audiui vulgarem linguæ Thamulicæ grammaticam criminantes
ut et ego exemplum vestrum sequutus, in ejus vineâ non inerti socordiâ sedeam. Valete.
Missne Madurensi, IV kal. Jan. M.D.CCXXVIII.

support.p: Same watermark as in manuscripts BnF Indien 189, 192, 617, and 634 (see Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 51). The watermark shows the letter T surmounted by a crown and placed on a base, itself surmounting a cartouche which contains a J followed by a fleur-de-lis and the name CUSSON (cf. nos. 3292 and 3293, pl. 424 and no. 694, pl. 109 in Heawood 1969 [1950]).

supportDesc.foliation: U1b: library roman pagination 1-89 on top (right or left) of page.

collation.desc: 1 folio = Grammar of Tamil (koṭun tamiḻ): Title Page. No foliation, no pagination.

45 folios = Grammar of Tamil (koṭun tamiḻ): Main Text. Library roman pagination 1-89. 89 written pages + 1 blank page. Written in several steps: see the different tones of the black ink in the two columns in p. 5.

layoutDesc.layout: Two rectangles drawn in grey pencil make the two columns within which the text is written. The margin on the four sides is 100 mm.

handNote.desc:
The hand seems to be that of Jean Calmette's (1692–1739/40) (compare fonds Brotier 89, ff. 21a, 25a, 51a). Calmette copied some of the manuscripts that were sent from India and entered the Royal library. See his letter from Ballabaram, August, 1731, in fonds Brotier 89, fol. 37a, 37b (non vidi, cited in Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 11).
The length of Tamil e and o is marked with a diacritic consisting in a horizontal stroke placed above the vowel. The horizontal stroke is also used above Tamil consonants to mark the vocalisation a.
The puḷḷi appears as a small circle above consonants in intermediate position.
The characters for ra and medial ā are not differentiated.

origin.origDate: The terminus a quo is 1728 indicated on the title page and at the end of the preface. It is not clear if it is the date of copy or just the date of composition of the work copied from a putative antigraph. The terminus ad quem is 1739 as the manuscript is described in the 1739 Catalogus (p. 444, n° CCII).
